support_summary: Sequestosome 1 (SQSTM1/p62) binds to the second catalytic domain of HDAC6 and decreases its deacetylase activity.

functions.cellular_process: Sequestosome 1 (SQSTM1/p62) directly interacts with the second catalytic domain (CD2) of HDAC6.
functions.effect_description: The binding of SQSTM1/p62 to HDAC6 inhibits its deacetylase activity. Consequently, the absence of p62 leads to the hyperactivation of HDAC6 and subsequent deacetylation of its substrates, such as α-tubulin and cortactin.
biological_consequence: SQSTM1/p62 binds to HDAC6 CD2 domain → HDAC6 deacetylase activity is inhibited → Acetylation of α-tubulin and cortactin increases → Regulation of F-actin network assembly and the aggresome-autophagy pathway is maintained → Facilitates successful autophagic clearance of protein aggregates.
specific_effects: The absence of p62 results in hyperactivation of HDAC6.
p62 is necessary for the perinuclear co-localization of cortactin-F-actin assemblies upon induction of protein misfolding.
The interaction plays a key role in regulating the recruitment of the F-actin network to the microtubule organizing center (MTOC) for clearance of protein aggregates.

evidence.paper_title: SQSTM1/p62 Interacts with HDAC6 and Regulates Deacetylase Activity
evidence.relevant_quote: We succeeded in identifying and mapping the direct interaction between HDAC6 and p62. We further show that this interaction regulates HDAC6 deacetylase activity. Data are presented demonstrating that the absence of p62 results in hyperactivation of HDAC6 and deacetylation of α-tubulin and cortactin.

evidence.paper_title: Regulation of HDAC6 Catalytic Activity in Cancer: The Role of Post-Translational Modifications and Protein–Protein Interactions
evidence.relevant_quote: The binding region of p62 on HDAC6 is localised to the 429–824 residues, which span the entire CD2 domain. Therefore, P62 binds to HDAC6 CD2 domain, inhibiting its deacetylase activity.
